section.title: Application Basics
section.para: An application is a computer program which is designed to perform a group of actions on a project.
The nature of the project depends on a specific implementation of an application.
Depending on the nature of a project, an application has typically one of the following application styles:

listitem.para: 'Utility'. Here, the application 'is' the project. The user can start the application and immediately perform actions, without ever having to select a project. Typical utility applications are: a calculator, a dictionary.

'Library-based'. Here, a project corresponds to a library. The user can start the application, and then the application automatically opens the previously used library (or libraries). The application provides actions on a library. Typically all changes are immediately made persistent in the library. Typical library-based applications are: a photo library, a music library.

'Document-based'. Here, a project corresponds to a file. The user can start the application, and open an existing file or create a new one. The application provides actions on a working copy of the file. Changes are only made persistent when the user explicitly saves them to the file. Typical document-based applications are: a text editor, a drawing editor.
